section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Crystals

embeddable.name: 1. This picture shows a crystal ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. This picture shows a crystal with a defect called a vacancy. How could you able to remove this kind of defect from a crystal?

choice.choice: a. By crushing the crystal and putting it under pressure squeezing the atoms together.
b. By dissolving the crystal in an acid and letting the acid evaporate leaving a perfect crystal.
c. We were not able to remove any vacancy defects in the activity.
d. We were able to remove vacancies by raising the temperature until it partially melted.

embeddable.name: 2. The pictures on the left ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. The pictures on the left and on the right are of the same material. What caused the difference?

choice.choice: a. The one on the right was crushed
b. The one on the right was dissolved
c. The one on the right was melted
d. The one on the right was exposed to light

embeddable.name: 3. The pictures 1, 2 and ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. The pictures 1, 2 and 3 are of the same material. Each picture represents what the material would look like under different conditions. Which picture shows the material with the least amount of energy?

choice.choice: a. Picture 1
b. Picture 2
c. Picture 3
d. They all have the same amount of energy.

embeddable.name: 4. This picture shows a crystal ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. This picture shows a crystal of AB3. What may happen to the crystalline structure if the crystal is put under tremendous pressure?

choice.choice: a. The crystal would not change under additional pressure.
b. The crystal would turn into a gas and evaporate destroying the crystal.
c. The crystal would alter its crystalline structure and the vacancies would be reduced in size.
d. The crystal would begin to melt as the pressure increased resulting in a larger version of the same crystal.

embeddable.name: 5. This picture shows two ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. This picture shows two crystals of AB3. What could have caused the difference between the two crystals?

choice.choice: a. crushing the crystal on the right and then putting it under pressure squeezing the atoms together.
b. dissolving the left crystal in an acid and letting the acid evaporate leaving vacancies in the crystal.
c. The crystals are polymorphs of the same material and formed that way.
d. The crystal on the left was heated to 400K creating the larger vacancies.

choice.choice: a. Picture 1
b. Picture 2
c. Picture 3

b. The crystal would turn into a gas and evaporate destroying the crystal.
c. The crystal would alter its crystalline structure and the vacancies would be reduced in size.
d. The crystal would begin to melt as the pressure increased resulting in a larger version of the same crystal.

embeddable.name: 5. This picture shows two ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. This picture shows two crystals of AB3. What could have caused the difference between the two crystals?

choice.choice: a. crushing the crystal on the right and then putting it under pressure squeezing the atoms together.
b. dissolving the left crystal in an acid and letting the acid evaporate leaving vacancies in the crystal.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Global Warming

embeddable.name: 1. The above diagram shows ...
embeddable.prompt:
1. The above diagram shows a model of the earth's atmosphere (blue) and earth surface (white and green). It shows a layer of snow on the surface.

How will the snow effect the amount of energy being absorbed by the earth?

choice.choice: a. The earth will absorb more energy from the sun because the snow is so cold and energy flows from hot to cold.
b. The earth will show no difference in the amount of energy being absorbed since the sun is giving off the same amount.
c. The earth will reflect a large amount of the energy from the sun because the snow is white and it reflects most of the light.
d. The earth will absorb more energy from the ground to melt the snow and increase the amount of moisture in the atmosphere.

embeddable.prompt: 2. If the greenhouses gases in the atmosphere were increased, what would happen to the amount of energy leaving the earth?

choice.choice: a. It would increase because the greenhouse gases would reflect more energy.
b. It would increase because the atmosphere would heat up releasing more energy into space.
c. It would decrease because more of it would be reflected back to the earth.
d. It would decease because less energy would be getting to the earth from the sun.

embeddable.prompt: 3. Which gas is not a greenhouse gas?

choice.choice: a. water vapor
b. nitrogen
c. carbon dioxide
d. methane

embeddable.name: 4. Why are greenhouse gases ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. Why are greenhouse gases called that?

choice.choice: a. They allow sunlight to shine through but block much of the heat from the dirt from leaving like a greenhouse.
b. They reflect most of the sunlight from hitting the dirt and keep the plants from burning like a greenhouse.
c. They allow the sunlight to shine through and allow the heat to leave but protect the plants from storms like a greenhouse.
d. They allow the green wavelengths of light to pass through to the plants but block out the other rays that would be harmful.

embeddable.name: If we took a Styrofoam cup ...
embeddable.prompt: If we took a Styrofoam cup and placed black soil in the bottom third of it, inserted a temperature probe through the side of the cup above the soil, and taped white paper over the opening of the cup, what would you predict the temperature would be after the cup was placed in the sun?

choice.choice: a. It would be warmer than a cup with dark soil in it and covered with a clear plastic wrap.
b. It would be warmer than a cup with dark soil in it and left uncovered.
c. It would be cooler than a cup with dark soil in it and covered with a clear plastic wrap.
d. It would be cooler than a cup with dark soil in it and left uncovered.

embeddable.name: If we took a Styrofoam cup ...
embeddable.prompt: If we took a Styrofoam cup and placed sand in the bottom third of it, inserted a temperature probe through the side of the cup above the sand, and covered the opening with clear plastic wrap, what would you predict the temperature would be after the cup was placed in the sun?

choice.choice: a. It would be warmer than a cup with dark soil in it.
b. It would be warmer than a cup with water in it.
c. It would be cooler than the dark soil
d. It would be cooler than all the cups

embeddable.prompt: In the above diagram of the model, what would be the major impact of increasing the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere?

choice.choice: a. The atmosphere would absorb more energy from the sun.
b. The atmosphere would reflect most of the energy from the sun.
c. The atmosphere would absorb more energy being radiated from the earth.
d. The atmosphere would have more moisture in it causing more rain on the surface.

embeddable.prompt: In the model the gases in the atmosphere were shown to ______________________.

choice.choice: a. Absorb most of the incoming energy from the source
b. Reflect a large amount of the energy coming from the earth
c. Reflect a large amount of the energy coming from the source
d. Create a significant amount of the energy found on the earth

embeddable.prompt: What would happen if we increased the amount of clouds in the sky?

choice.choice: a. The increased amount of clouds would increase the amount of light reflected back into space.
b. The increased cloud layer would increase the amount of gases in the atmosphere.
c. The increased amount of clouds would decrease the amount of energy radiated from the earth.
d. The increased clouds would increase the amount of energy coming from the sun to the earth.

embeddable.prompt: What would happen if we increased the amount of energy from the sun reaching the earth?

choice.choice: a. The increased amount of energy would increase the amount of clouds due to increased evaporation.
b. The increased energy would result in a large change in the kind of gases in the atmosphere and how it absorbs energy.
c. The additional energy would not impact the earth because the amount reflected would increase as well keeping the overall temperature of the earth the same.
d. The increased energy would increase the total amount of energy being absorbed by the earth and increase the temperature of the earth.

embeddable.prompt:
In the above diagram of the model, we have added a layer of snow on the surface.

How will the snow affect the amount of energy being absorbed by the earth?

choice.choice: a. The earth would absorb more energy from the sun because the snow is so cold and energy flows from hot to cold.
b. The earth will show no difference in the amount of energy being absorbed since the sun is giving off the same amount.

c. The earth will reflect a large amount of the energy from the sun because the snow is white and it reflects most of the light.c. The earth will reflect a large amount of the energy from the sun because the snow is white and it reflects most of the light.
d. The earth will absorb more energy from the ground to melt the snow and increase the amount of moisture in the atmosphere.

embeddable.prompt: The red dots represent energy in the earth. Where did the majority of the energy come from in the model?

choice.choice: a. Molecules of gases in the air
c. Energy coming from the earth’s interior
b. Radiation coming from the sun
d. Energy reflected back from the clouds

embeddable.prompt: What gas was not included as a greenhouse gas in the model?

choice.choice: a. water vapor
b. nitrogen
c. carbon dioxide
d. methane

embeddable.prompt: If the greenhouse gases continue to increase what would be the logical impact on the strength of storms around the globe?

choice.choice: d. It would make the storms more intense since the increased greenhouse gases would increase the temperature of the atmosphere and increase the convection within it.

embeddable.prompt: If we increased the greenhouses gases what would happen to the amount of energy leaving the earth?

choice.choice: d. It would decease because less energy would be getting to the earth from the sun.

embeddable.prompt: If we drastically reduced the amount of greenhouse gases that were released into the atmosphere by human activity, how would it impact the flow of energy on earth?

choice.choice: a. It would increase the amount of energy reaching the earth’s surface because there would be less gas to reflect it back into space.
b. It would decrease the energy absorbed by the earth because the atmospheric albedo would increase by not have dirty gases in it
c. It would increase the amount of energy leaving the earth because there would be fewer greenhouse gas molecules reflecting the heat back to the earth.
d. It would decrease the total energy of the earth because the oceans would absorb more energy from the atmosphere.

embeddable.prompt: If a large volcanic eruption occurred in Antarctica, and it covered the south polar area with dark ash, what would happen to the average albedo of the earth?

choice.choice: d. It would make little or no difference in the earth’s albedo since Antarctica is such a small portion of the earth’s surface.

embeddable.prompt: In the above activity the Earth is receiving the energy from the sun through what process?

choice.choice: d. Evaporation

embeddable.prompt: If we took a Styrofoam cup and placed black soil in the bottom third of it , inserted a temperature probe through the side of the cup above the soil , covered the opening with clear plastic wrap, what would the graph of the temperature look like after being placed in the sun?

choice.choice: a. It would increase steadily
b. It would increase and then level off at about 26 degrees C
c. The temperature would not change at all
d. The temperature would decrease slowly

embeddable.prompt: If we took a Styrofoam cup and placed water in the bottom third of it , inserted a temperature probe through the side of the cup above the water , covered the opening with clear plastic wrap, what would the graph of the temperature look like after being placed in the sun?

choice.choice: a. It would increase steadily up to about 40 degrees C
b. It would increase steadily but not as high as a
c. The temperature would not change at all
d. The temperature would decrease slowly

embeddable.prompt: Why would a gardener want to paint the windows of a green house white in the summer?

choice.choice: d. It would allow the sunlight into the greenhouse but block more of the light from coming out.

embeddable.prompt: Why are greenhouse gases called greenhouse?

choice.choice: a. They allow sunlight to shine through but block much of the heat from the dirt from leaving like a greenhouse.
b. They reflect most of the sunlight from hitting the dirt and keep the plants from burning like a greenhouse.
c. They allow the sunlight to shine through and allow the heat to leave but protect the plants from storms like a greenhouse.
d. They allow the green wavelengths of light to pass through to the plants but block out the other rays that would be harmful.

embeddable.prompt:
1. The above diagram shows a model of the earth's atmosphere (blue) and earth surface (white and green). It shows a layer of snow on the surface.

embeddable.prompt: 2. If the greenhouses gases in the atmosphere were increased, what would happen to the amount of energy leaving the earth?

c. It would decrease because more of it would be reflected back to the earth.
d. It would decease because less energy would be getting to the earth from the sun.

embeddable.name: 3. Which gas is not a greenhouse ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. Which gas is not a greenhouse gas?

choice.choice: a. water vapor
b. nitrogen
c. carbon dioxide
d. methane

embeddable.name: 4. Why are greenhouse gases ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. Why are greenhouse gases called that?

choice.choice: a. They allow sunlight to shine through but block much of the heat from the dirt from leaving like a greenhouse.
b. They reflect most of the sunlight from hitting the dirt and keep the plants from burning like a greenhouse.
c. They allow the sunlight to shine through and allow the heat to leave but protect the plants from storms like a greenhouse.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Solar System

embeddable.name: 1. This is a model of a Space ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. This is a model of a Space Station being launched from the surface of the earth. At what angle would you expect to have the Space Station travel the greatest range no matter which launch speed was selected?

choice.choice: a. 0 degrees
b. 20 degrees
c. 40 degrees
d. 100 degrees

embeddable.name: 2. In this picture, a cannon ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. In this picture, a cannon is launching the space station from several different angles. Which of the lines represents the flight of the space station shot at an angle of 45 degrees?

choice.choice: a
b
c
d

embeddable.name: 3. The picture shown above ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. The picture shown above simulates the planetary orbits of our solar system. What can be said about the orbits of the four innermost planets as compared to the outer two planets (Jupiter and Saturn)?

choice.choice: a. The inner most planets have orbital periods that are longer than the periods of the other planets.
b. The planets that are further from the sun have orbital periods that are almost as long as the inner planets.
c. The planets that are further from the sun have orbital periods that are longer than those near the sun.
d. The closer to the sun the planet is the more elliptical the orbit of that is going to be due to the gravity of the sun.

embeddable.name: 4. The earth rotates from ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. The earth rotates from west to east at about 0.3 km/sec. What direction would be the best for launching a satellite?

choice.choice: a. straight up
b. toward the west, against the earth's rotation
c. toward the east, with the earth's rotation
d. toward the equator

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Earthquakes

embeddable.name: 1. In a map of earthquake ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. In a map of earthquake locations around the world it is noticed that earthquakes are most often located near what geological feature?

choice.choice: a. Earthquakes are most often found near volcanoes.
b. Earthquakes are always located in mountain ranges near the edge of continents.
c. Earthquakes are most often found in the deepest part of the ocean.
d. Earthquakes are most often found near plate boundaries.

embeddable.name: 2. Why does the western coast ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. Why does the western coast of the United States and Alaska have more earthquakes than the east coast?

choice.choice: a. The nearest plate boundary to the east coast is found in the Atlantic ridge or near Cuba.
b. The western United States and Alaska are located very near plate boundaries.
c. Because the West coast of the United States is made of weak rock material.
d. Because the West coast of the United States and Alaska has large numbers of volcanoes.

embeddable.name: 3. What can generally be ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. What can generally be said about earthquake depth and magnitude?

choice.choice: a. Deep earthquakes are very often the strongest.
b. There is no relationship between depth and magnitude of earthquakes.
c. Shallow earthquakes tend to be stronger than deeper ones.
d. Shallow earthquakes often tend to shake the longest.

embeddable.name: 4. As you move from a plate ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. As you move from a plate boundary and go in towards the center of a continent, what will happen to the depth of the earthquake in most cases?

choice.choice: a. Within a couple of hundred km the depth of the earthquakes will get deeper.
b. Within a couple of hundred km the depth of the earthquakes will get shallower.
c. Within a couple of hundred km there would be no significant difference in depth of the earthquakes.
d. The depth of the earthquakes would depend on the time of year you are traveling.

embeddable.name: 5. Volcanoes are most often ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. Volcanoes are most often associated with what geological feature?

choice.choice: a. Deep ocean basins
b. Continental interiors
c. Plate boundaries
d. Ocean trenches

embeddable.name: 1. Using this rapid response ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. Using this rapid response temperature senor, what would you expect would happen to the temperature measured by the senor, if the gauze was made wet with room temperature water, the air was very dry, and you had a fan blowing across it?

choice.choice: a. The temperature would not change at all.
b. The temperature would drop.
c. The temperature would increase.
d. The temperature would increase and then drop.

embeddable.prompt: 2. If it was raining, the relative humidity of the air outside would be closer to what percent?

embeddable.name: 3. Using the above Temperature ...

B
C
D

choice.choice: A
B
C
D

b. line 4

d. The pressure varies based on the type of front.

b. line 4
c. It depends on the humidity prior to the storm.
d. It depends on whether it's daytime or nighttime.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Greenhouse

embeddable.name: 1. If we took a Styrofoam ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. If we took a Styrofoam cup and placed sand in the bottom third of it , inserted a temperature probe through the side of the cup above the sand , covered the opening with clear plastic wrap, what would you predict the temperature would be after being placed in the sun?

choice.choice: a. It would be warmer than a cup with dark soil in it.
b. It would be cooler than a cup with dark soil.
c. It would be warmer than a cup with water in it.
d. It would be warmer than an empty cup.

embeddable.name: 2. Why would a gardener want ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. Why would a gardener want to paint the windows of a green house white in the summer?

choice.choice: a. It would allow more light into the green house and speed up plant growth.
b. It would reflect a lot of the sunlight and keep the greenhouse cooler.
c. It would filter out the harmful infrared rays and keep the plants from burning.
d. It would allow the sunlight into the greenhouse but block more of the light from coming out.

embeddable.name: 3. If we took a Styrofoam ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. If we took a Styrofoam cup and placed black soil in the bottom third of it , inserted a temperature probe through the side of the cup above the soil, and taped white paper over the opening of the cup, what would you predict the temperature would be after being placed in the sun?

choice.choice: a. It would be warmer than a cup covered with a clear plastic wrap.
b. It would be warmer than a cup left uncovered.
c. It would be cooler than a cup covered with a clear plastic wrap.
d. It would be cooler than a cup left uncovered.

embeddable.name: 4. Which curve best represents ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. Which curve best represents the light level in a greenhouse in June in the Northern Hemisphere?

choice.choice: A
B
C
D

embeddable.name: 5. What would be the best ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. What would be the best way to regulate the temperature of a greenhouse in the summer?

choice.choice: a. Seal up the openings.
b. Install a fan in a window.
c. Paint the glass black.
d. Add dirt to the floor.

embeddable.name: 1. If we took a Styrofoam ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. If we took a Styrofoam cup and placed sand in the bottom third of it , inserted a temperature probe through the side of the cup above the sand , covered the opening with clear plastic wrap, what would you predict the temperature would be after being placed in the sun?

choice.choice: a. It would be warmer than a cup with dark soil in it.
b. It would be cooler than a cup with dark soil.
c. It would be warmer than a cup with water in it.
d. It would be warmer than an empty cup.

embeddable.name: 2. Why would a gardener want ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. Why would a gardener want to paint the windows of a green house white in the summer?

choice.choice: a. It would allow more light into the green house and speed up plant growth.
b. It would reflect a lot of the sunlight and keep the greenhouse cooler.
c. It would filter out the harmful infrared rays and keep the plants from burning.
d. It would allow the sunlight into the greenhouse but block more of the light from coming out.

embeddable.name: 3. If we took a Styrofoam ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. If we took a Styrofoam cup and placed black soil in the bottom third of it , inserted a temperature probe through the side of the cup above the soil, and taped white paper over the opening of the cup, what would you predict the temperature would be after being placed in the sun?

choice.choice: a. It would be warmer than a cup covered with a clear plastic wrap.
b. It would be warmer than a cup left uncovered.
c. It would be cooler than a cup covered with a clear plastic wrap.
d. It would be cooler than a cup left uncovered.

embeddable.name: 4. Which curve best represents ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. Which curve best represents the light level in a greenhouse in June in the Northern Hemisphere?

choice.choice: A
B
C
D

embeddable.name: 5. What would be the best ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. What would be the best way to regulate the temperature of a greenhouse in the summer?

choice.choice: a. Seal up the openings.
b. Install a fan in a window.
c. Paint the glass black.
d. Add dirt to the floor.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Human Response

embeddable.name: 1. In the test of reaction ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. In the test of reaction time pictured above, one person drops a ruler and the other tries to catch it as quickly as possible. How should the sense of touch compare to the sense of sight in terms of reaction time?

choice.choice: a. There would be no difference.
b. The sense of touch would be faster.
c. The sense of sight would be faster.
d. It depends on the individual.

embeddable.name: 2. If you wet one hand with ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. If you wet one hand with room temperature water and then placed both hands in front of a fan, which hand would feel cooler?

choice.choice: a. The dry hand would feel cooler because the wind would not be blocked by the water on the hand.
b. The wet hand would feel cooler because as the water evaporates it takes heat from the hand.
c. There would be no difference in the way the hands would feel in the fan.
d. The wet hand would feel warmer because the water would insulate the hand from the wind.

embeddable.name: 3. The picture is a diagram ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. The picture is a diagram of human vocal cords. How would the vocal cords work to make a high-pitched sound?

choice.choice: a. The lungs would force a fast stream of air past the relaxed vocal cords.
b. The lungs would force a stream of air past tightly stretched vocal cords.
c. The shape of your mouth determines the pitch.
d. Both the nose and the mouth are involved in pitch.

embeddable.name: 4. The picture is a diagram ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. The picture is a diagram of a human ear. If the ear drum is made of a tightly stretched piece of skin, what might happen if the ear drum was hit by vibrations that were very strong and over a long period of time?

choice.choice: a. The skin could tear and the sound vibrations entering the ear would not be detected by the brain.
b. The skin would repair itself over time and there would be no damage done to the person's hearing.
c. The skin is very tough and would not be damaged by just sound vibrations coming from outside the body.
d. The skin could tear but it would have no real impact on hearing since the cochlea would take over the role.

embeddable.name: 5. When you touch an object ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. When you touch an object with your finger it may feel cooler or warmer depending on the energy conductive nature of the material being touched. In the diagrams below, your finger touches the plate to the left, and the color of the rectangles represents the temperature of the plate (white = cool, red = hot). In which sample would you say your finger would feel cooler when touching the plate?

choice.choice: a. There is no difference between the two samples and therefore they would both feel the same.
b. Sample 1 would feel cooler because it is taking less heat from the finger.
c. Sample 1 would feel cooler because it is taking more heat from the finger.
d. Sample 2 would feel cooler because it is taking more heat from the finger.

embeddable.name: 1. In the test of reaction ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. In the test of reaction time pictured above, one person drops a ruler and the other tries to catch it as quickly as possible. How should the sense of touch compare to the sense of sight in terms of reaction time?

choice.choice: a. There would be no difference.
b. The sense of touch would be faster.
c. The sense of sight would be faster.
d. It depends on the individual.

embeddable.prompt: 2. If you wet one hand with room temperature water and then placed both hands in front of a fan, which hand would feel cooler?

choice.choice: a. The dry hand would feel cooler because the wind would not be blocked by the water on the hand.

c. There would be no difference in the way the hands would feel in the fan.

In which sample would you say your finger would feel cooler when touching the plate?

choice.choice: a. There is no difference between the two samples and therefore they would both feel the same.
b. Sample 1 would feel cooler because it is taking less heat from the finger.
c. Sample 1 would feel cooler because it is taking more heat from the finger.
d. Sample 2 would feel cooler because it is taking more heat from the finger.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Populations

embeddable.name: 1. The graph shows populations ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. The graph shows populations of rabbits (red), grass (green), and weeds (purple) over time. The rabbits get their food from eating grass. What does the graph show happens when the grass grow rate is decreased almost in half?

choice.choice: a. As the grass grow rate decreased the population of rabbits also decreased.
b. As the rabbit population grew the amount of grass decreased.
c. The graph shows no relationship between the amount of rabbits and the amount of grass.
d. As the rabbit population decreased, the amount of grass increased in the same amount.

embeddable.name: 2. What does the graph show ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. What does the graph show happened over time with the population of rabbits and the amount of grass?

choice.choice: a. As time passed the graph shows that as the rabbit population grew so did the amount of grass.
b. As time passed the graph shows that as the rabbit population grew the amount of grass decreased.
c. The graph shows no relationship between the amount of rabbits and the amount of grass.
d. The graph shows that the size of the rabbit population would grow forever.

embeddable.name: 3. At what point in the graph ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. At what point in the graph did the amount of energy gained by eating the grass and weeds become much less?

embeddable.name: 4. What does the graph show ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. What does the graph show happens over time when the grass grow rate is increased to the point of unlimited food for the rabbits?

choice.choice: a. The graph shows that the rabbit population continued to increase.
b. The graph shows that the rabbit population grew and then leveled off.
c. The graph shows no relationship between the amount of rabbits and the amount of grass.
d. The graph shows that the size of the rabbit population is not related to the amount of food.

embeddable.name: 5. If a rabbit population ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. If a rabbit population was introduced onto an island where rabbits did not live before what could happen to the island's population of living things?

choice.choice: a. Nothing would change; the rabbit population would just become part of the food chain.
b. As time passed the rabbit population could destroy much of the food supply on the island.
c. The introduction of a rabbit population would increase the food supply for all living things on the island.
d. The rabbits would always die off for lack of familiar food.

c. ribosome
d. cytoplasm

b. starch
c. cellulose
d. cholesterol

embeddable.prompt: 3. Why are lipids good building blocks for membranes that separate cells from one another?

choice.choice: a. They are strongly bonded to each other.
b. They are non-polar.
c. They are polar.
d. One end is polar and the other end is non-polar.

embeddable.prompt: 4. DNA is a polymer which is typically constructed from four different monomers, called nucleotides. Which is not a DNA nucleotide?

choice.choice: a. Lysine
b. Guanine
c. Cytosine
d. Adenine

embeddable.name: 5. Which is not a common ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. Which is not a common element in proteins?

choice.choice: a. carbon
b. oxygen
c. iron
d. nitrogen

embeddable.prompt: 6. What is the molecular building block of carbohydrates?

choice.choice: a. sucrose

embeddable.prompt: 1. Here are some chromosomes for a dragon. What gender is the dragon?

choice.choice: a. There is insufficient information.
b. male, because one chromosome has dominant horns
c. male, because there is no Y chromosome
d. female, because there are two X chromosomes

embeddable.name: 2. In the process of meiosis ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. In the process of meiosis how many germs cells are involved in the Mother or the Father ?

embeddable.name: 3. When Hilda the female ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. When Hilda the female dragon has an offspring with Landar the male dragon, why does the offspring dragon look different from both the female and male parents?

choice.choice: a. There really is no difference between the offspring and its parent dragons.
b. During the fertilization process the offspring mutated and changed its appearance.
c. During the fertilization process the offspring received half of its traits from the male the other half from the female.
d. During the fertilization process the offspring received all of its traits from one of the two dragons.

embeddable.name: 4. In the process of meiosis ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. In the process of meiosis how many sets of chromosomes does each gamete have?

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Heat and Temperature

embeddable.name: 1. Which would be the
embeddable.prompt: 1. Which would be the worst conductor for transferring energy between two substances?

choice.choice: a. gas
b. thick short bar
c. vacuum
d. sponge

embeddable.name: 2. When you stand next to ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. When you stand next to a fire you feel the warmth from the fire. If gas is a poor conductor of heat, how is the energy from the fire reaching your body?

choice.choice: a. Even though gas is a bad conductor of heat, given enough time the heat would be conducted.
b. The energy is really traveling through the ground or floor and up your legs, making you feel warm.
c. The fire is giving off photons that are carrying energy, you feel warm when you absorb the photons.
d. the fire is setting up convection currents that move the air in a circular pattern bringing the heat to you.

embeddable.name: 3. In a container there are ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. In a container there are two gases whose molecules have different masses. What can you tell about the average kinetic energy of the molecules of each kind?

choice.choice: a. The less massive molecules [yellow] have more kinetic energy.
b. The more massive molecules [pink] have more kinetic energy.
c. The more massive molecules [pink] have much more kinetic energy.
d. The molecules of both gases have approximately the same kinetic energy .

embeddable.name: 4. As the temperature of ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. As the temperature of a container increases what happens to the motion of the molecules of gas inside?

choice.choice: a. They slow down
b. They move faster
c. The motion does not change no matter what the temperature
d. They move faster but then begin to slow down

embeddable.name: 5. Suppose you mixed 50 ml ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. Suppose you mixed 50 ml of water at 20°C with 100 ml of water at 40°C. What would the final temperature be?

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Molecular Motion

embeddable.name: 1. In this model of particles ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. In this model of particles (purple) moving in water, one particle makes a sudden change in direction at the point marked with the arrow. What made the particle change direction?

choice.choice: a. It is alive and decided to move in another direction.
b. A current from a nearby particle changed the direction of this particle.
c. A particle coming from the top hit the particle and it caused to change direction.
d. a nuclear reaction

embeddable.name: 2. In a room full of gas ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. In a room full of gas particles, what best describes the motion of the particles?

choice.choice: a. the number of particles in the room
b. the temperature of the room
c. the color and weight of the particles
d. the size of the particles

embeddable.name: 3. In a container filled ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. In a container filled with water, a dye was injected into the bottom right-hand corner. How is the dye moving throughout the container?

choice.choice: a. The dye molecules are randomly bumped by surrounding water molecules.
b. The dye moves under its own energy throughout the container.
c. The force of the injection caused the dye to move throughout the container.
d. The magnetic attraction of water molecules carries the dye molecules across the container.

embeddable.name: 4. Perfume has been sprayed ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. Perfume has been sprayed into the air in one corner of the room. What could affect how fast the perfume diffuses throughout the room?

choice.choice: a. By cooling the air in the room the perfume would diffuse faster.
b. By heating the air in the room the perfume would diffuse faster.
c. There is nothing that could be done to diffuse the perfume faster.
d. By cooling the perfume it would diffuse throughout the room faster.

embeddable.name: 1. In this model of particles ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. In this model of particles (purple) moving in water, one particle makes a sudden change in direction at the point marked with the arrow. What made the particle change direction?

choice.choice: a. It is alive and decided to move in another direction.
b. A current from a nearby particle changed the direction of this particle.
c. A particle coming from the top hit the particle and it caused to change direction.
d. a nuclear reaction

embeddable.name: 2. In a room full of gas ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. In a room full of gas particles, what best describes the motion of the particles?

choice.choice: a. the number of particles in the room
b. the temperature of the room
c. the color and weight of the particles
d. the size of the particles

embeddable.name: 3. In a container filled ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. In a container filled with water, a dye was injected into the bottom right-hand corner. How is the dye moving throughout the container?

choice.choice: a. The dye molecules are randomly bumped by surrounding water molecules.
b. The dye moves under its own energy throughout the container.
c. The force of the injection caused the dye to move throughout the container.
d. The magnetic attraction of water molecules carries the dye molecules across the container.

embeddable.name: 4. Perfume has been sprayed ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. Perfume has been sprayed into the air in one corner of the room. What could affect how fast the perfume diffuses throughout the room?

choice.choice: a. By cooling the air in the room the perfume would diffuse faster.
b. By heating the air in the room the perfume would diffuse faster.
c. There is nothing that could be done to diffuse the perfume faster.
d. By cooling the perfume it would diffuse throughout the room faster.

section.description: describe the purpose of this section here...
section.name: Motion

embeddable.name: 1. In this graph what is ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. In this graph what is the best description of your motion at times 1, 2, 3, and 4?

choice.choice: a. just standing still
b. jumping up and down
c. moving towards the sensor
d. moving away from the sensor

embeddable.name: 2. If you were walking and ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. If you were walking and you just moved toward and away from a location, your graph of the distance from that location would look something like this. At which time would you have been moving toward the location?

embeddable.name: 3. As a bat is flying, which ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. As a bat is flying, which of the following descriptions best describes how the bat uses sound to find its food?

choice.choice: a. The closer the insect, the less time it takes for the sound to reflect back to the bat.
b. The closer the insect, the more time it takes for the sound to reflect back to the bat.
c. The bigger the insect, the softer the sound reflection will be.
d. The further the insect, the louder the reflected sound.

embeddable.name: 4. In this motion graph, ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. In this motion graph, at what time were you moving the slowest?

embeddable.name: 5. At what time in the motion ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. At what time in the motion graph was the person running toward the sensor?

embeddable.name: 6. According to the graph ...
embeddable.prompt: 6. According to the graph , what was the farthest the person was from zero?

choice.choice: b. 1 m

section.name: Phase Change

embeddable.name: 1. What state of matter would ...
embeddable.prompt: 1. What state of matter would this be if each object in the picture were an atom?

choice.choice: a. solid
b. liquid
c. gas
d. plasma

embeddable.name: 2. What state of matter would ...
embeddable.prompt: 2. What state of matter would this be if each object in the picture were an atom?

choice.choice: a. solid
b. liquid
c. gas
d. plasma

embeddable.name: 3. At what temperature did ...
embeddable.prompt: 3. At what temperature did the above material begin to change state from a solid to a liquid?

choice.choice: a. 0 degrees K
b. .5 degrees K
c. 1.2 degrees K
d. 1.6 degrees K

embeddable.name: 4. A pan of water containing ...
embeddable.prompt: 4. A pan of water containing a large ice cube is placed over a hot flame and the water is stirred constantly. At what point will the temperature of the water rise?

choice.choice: a. as soon as the pan is over the flame
b. as soon as the ice begins to melt
c. after all the ice melts
d. when the water begins to boil

embeddable.name: 5. What state of matter has ...
embeddable.prompt: 5. What state of matter has the weakest attraction between atoms?

choice.choice: a. solid
b. liquid
c. gas
d. They all have the same attraction no matter what state.

embeddable.name: 6. Ice can be added to water ...
embeddable.prompt: 6. Ice can be added to water to cool it down. Why is ice for this purpose than just adding the same mass of water at 0°C?

choice.choice: a. Ice is denser than water.
b. It take energy to melt ice.
c. Ice is colder than water at 0°C.
d. Water in its liquid state has stronger bonds than ice.
